If your opponent doesn't understand what logical fallacies are or are not aware that they are committing them, it can be challenging to call them out. Here are some tips to handle the situation:

1. Define logical fallacies - Start by defining logical fallacies in clear and simple terms. Explain how they can weaken an argument and lead to erroneous conclusions.

2. Offer examples - Provide examples of logical fallacies that are relevant to the conversation. Use real-world scenarios or hypothetical examples to help your opponent better understand the concept.

3. Provide resources - Offer resources like book chapters or websites to help your opponent learn about logical fallacies. This can help them see that you are not alone in your thinking and that there are experts in the field.

4. Use neutral sources - Use sources that are generally trusted and reliable, such as universities or academic research, to help illustrate the concept of logical fallacies.

5. Don't be condescending - Avoid being condescending or dismissive of your opponent. Instead, approach the conversation with a respectful and patient tone.

Remember, education on logical fallacies takes time, practice, and patience. By being clear, concise, and patient, you might be able to teach your opponent about logical fallacies and improve the overall quality of your debate.
